instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi I have a board missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
Cpu prerequisites:
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>=3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>=3.32v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>=3.24v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>=.489mv
<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL>=.489mv
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>=2.7v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>=3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>= 3.4mv
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>=3.45v

I also have power <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> on pins 8,5 but not on pin 1 (<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CS_L</SIGNAL>)=.489v

Shouldn’t the bios output 3.3 on pin 1 ? Is it a bios or Should I try that trick of hearing cpu like on the last board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>=v"
???

"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>=2.7v"
Post <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> level and <TRANSISTOR>Q7802</TRANSISTOR>/20 voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>= .489mv
I’m not sure but the brd file say pin 1 of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> is 
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> =0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>= .489mv"
Do you mean <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> instead?
Check <RESISTOR>R1915</RESISTOR>.

threads.message:

It measures 193k not the 390k it supposed to

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Broken trace???
Pin 2/<RESISTOR>R1915</RESISTOR> is <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>.
Where did you check it before, as that is the only point accessible???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I’m sorry I was Hurricane preparing.  no it’s was a bad solder joint. It’s good now <RESISTOR>R1915</RESISTOR> pin2=3.2v  checked it multiple times. Touched up the joint. Now on to why my <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is low
I’m going to check the Level of <TRANSISTOR>Q7802</TRANSISTOR>/20 voltages.
As you suggested

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
At <TRANSISTOR>Q7802</TRANSISTOR>
Pins:
1-GND
2-<SIGNAL>P3V3_S4_EN</SIGNAL>= 479mv
3-<SIGNAL>P3V3SUS_EN_L</SIGNAL>= 3.3v
4-GND
5-<SIGNAL>PM_SUS_EN</SIGNAL>=0
6-<SIGNAL>PP3V3S4_EN_L</SIGNAL>=0

<TRANSISTOR>Q7820</TRANSISTOR>
Pins:
1- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>=3.3v
2-<SIGNAL>P3V3SUS_SS</SIGNAL>=3.3v
3-<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=3.3v
4-<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok I grounded <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> at <CAPACITOR>C5710</CAPACITOR> and the <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R2502</RESISTOR> Ok yes it did drop down to 400mv and went back up to 1.6v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"yes it did drop down to 400mv and went back up to 1.6v"
It should have 3.3V in normal state; check it with KB disconnected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The logic board is bare on my desk nothing connected When I tested it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Do you have steady 3V at <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>= 3.44v and steady

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"it did drop down to 400mv and went back up to 1.6v"
Then what this mean?

Check if all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals pulse at same time when <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Ok my mistake. When you ask me to short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground and check to see if I had a drop in voltage at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> yes it does drop down to 400mv and then back up to 1.6v and when I said  "it did drop down to 400mv and went back up to 1.6v" I was referring to <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>
I will check to see if all the sleep signals “<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL>” pulse at the same time as
“ <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>” thank you for your help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> also MUST go back to 3V when you realease power button.
In fact, it should be steady 3V and only drops when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok cool I’ll check that as well and report back

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Ok on <RESISTOR>R1985</RESISTOR> on pin 1 =3.3v on pin 2=1.6v
I removed <RESISTOR>R1985</RESISTOR> and measured it is 1k what schematic say is correct. When I power the board with out resistor I get pin 1= 3.3v and pin 2 = 1.6v so the 1.6 is either coming from smc or pch. I get 1.6v from Both pins of <RESISTOR>R2502</RESISTOR> With <RESISTOR>R1985</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R2585</RESISTOR> removed. But on the schematic it say “in” to smc :( so is this signal being sent by pch low ? Or should I remove <RESISTOR>R2502</RESISTOR>?

I will post the “<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL>“ signals as soon as I figure out why <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> is low as of now the sleep signals are 0v but I’m guessing that has a lot todo with the resistors I have removed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I will post the “<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL>“ signals as soon as I figure out why <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> is low as of now the sleep signals are 0v but I’m guessing that has a lot todo with the resistors I have removed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Either PCH, or SMC pull down <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
You can try heating PCH with quality flux, to discard an issue created by accumulated crap underneath.
Also do the same with SMC...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Ok will do 180 degrees with AMTECH flux on both and no it didn’t anything. I reinstalled <RESISTOR>R1985</RESISTOR> testEd with <RESISTOR>R2502</RESISTOR> Removed and  I have 3.42v coming from smc on on pin 1 of the location of <RESISTOR>R2502</RESISTOR> with resistor removes . Is this correct? 3.42v out from pin 49 of smc? 

I tested at the location of <RESISTOR>R1985</RESISTOR> without resistor and at first it was 3.3v on pin 1, pin 2 had zero. I held it there for 20 seconds then the 1.6v came up again. What else could be leaking voltage on this line as I have found nothing else connected ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R1985</RESISTOR> pulls-up <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
SMC, or PCH can only sink current.
One of them is bad, or corrosion between balls pulls-down the signal.
